message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is at risk for hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) due to her blood type being Rh+ and her partner’s being Rh-. The results of the complete blood count and electrophoresis show that she has thalassemia trait and her husband does not. The fetus is showing signs of hydrops fetalis, indicating severe anemia. Cordocentesis can be performed for both diagnostic (to assess the fetus’ blood type and hemoglobin concentration) and therapeutic (to perform intrauterine blood transfusion) purposes in this case. Fetoscopy and amniocentesis do not provide information about the fetal blood type or allow for intrauterine blood transfusion. Fetal thoracentesis is not appropriate for this case as it only addresses the pleural effusion and not the underlying cause of the hydrops fetalis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN), which can be caused by Rh incompatibility. Cordocentesis, also called percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), can both diagnose and treat HDFN by performing blood transfusions or administering medications directly to the fetus’s bloodstream. Fetoscopy and percutaneous fetal thoracentesis are diagnostic but not therapeutic. Amniocentesis is not helpful in this case because it only provides information on genetic abnormalities and not on fetal anemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery along with the ultrasound findings indicate that the fetus may have Hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN). The complete blood count and electrophoresis results show that the patient has beta-thalassemia trait, which could result in hemolytic disease in the fetus. Cordocentesis can be performed for diagnostic purposes to determine the fetal blood type and hemoglobin levels, and for therapeutic purposes to perform blood transfusion or intrauterine exchange transfusion if necessary. Fetoscopy, amniocentesis, and percutaneous fetal thoracentesis are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s blood work and electrophoresis results suggest that she carries beta-thalassemia trait and her husband does not. The ultrasound findings suggest fetal hydrops, which could be caused by beta-thalassemia major in the fetus. Cordocentesis can be used to confirm the diagnosis of beta-thalassemia major in the fetus and also perform transfusion in case of severe fetal anemia. It can be both diagnostic and therapeutic. Fetoscopy and percutaneous fetal thoracentesis are purely diagnostic procedures, and amniocentesis cannot provide information on fetal hemoglobin levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the history and findings, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-thalassemia major. Cordocentesis (option C) can be used for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in this case. It can be used to obtain a sample of fetal blood for genetic testing and to perform intrauterine blood transfusion to help manage fetal anemia in cases of alpha-thalassemia major. None of the other options are appropriate for this case. Fetoscopy is an invasive prenatal diagnostic procedure that allows visualization of the fetus and sampling of fetal tissue, but it is not useful for managing fetal anemia. Amniocentesis is used to obtain amniotic fluid for genetic testing and can also be used to assess fetal lung maturity, but it is not useful for managing fetal anemia or ascites. Percutaneous fetal thoracentesis is a therapeutic procedure that can be used to drain pleural fluid in cases of fetal hydrops, but it is not useful for managing fetal anemia or ascites.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's blood count and electrophoresis results show that she has beta-thalassemia trait and her partner does not carry the same trait. The presenting symptoms in the fetus suggest that the baby is likely affected with thalassemia major, which requires early diagnosis and intervention. Cordocentesis can be used for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes as it allows for examination of fetal blood and can be used to perform in utero blood transfusions. Fetoscopy, amniocentesis, and percutaneous fetal thoracentesis do not provide access to fetal blood and are not useful in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient and her partner both have normal hemoglobin levels but there is a possibility of thalassemia in the family due to the patient's grandfather's symptoms. The fetal ultrasound shows signs of hydrops fetalis, which can be caused by thalassemia major. Cordocentesis can be performed to obtain fetal blood for genetic testing and to transfuse the fetus with packed red blood cells if needed, which can be both diagnostic and therapeutic in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s blood count and electrophoresis results suggest beta thalassemia trait. The ultrasound examination and elevated peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery suggest fetal anemia. Cordocentesis, also known as percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), can be performed for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in this case. It can be used to diagnose and manage fetal anemia in utero by measuring the oxygen-carrying capacity of the fetal blood, and providing blood transfusion if necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation is consistent with fetal anemia, which can be caused by hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) in which the mother's antibodies attack the fetal red blood cells due to a mismatched blood type. Cordocentesis (also known as percutaneous umbilical blood sampling or PUBS) can be performed to obtain a sample of fetal blood to diagnose and treat HDN through intrauterine blood transfusion. Fetoscopy, amniocentesis, and percutaneous fetal thoracentesis do not allow for direct access to fetal blood.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with fetal ascites, liver enlargement, and pleural effusion with elevated peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery, which indicate fetal anemia. Cordocentesis can be performed for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in this case. It involves the aspiration of fetal blood from the umbilical vein for analysis, as well as the transfusion of blood products if necessary. Fetoscopy is a diagnostic procedure that involves inserting a small camera through the abdomen into the amniotic fluid to view the fetus. Amniocentesis involves the aspiration of amniotic fluid for diagnostic purposes, such as genetic testing. Percutaneous fetal thoracentesis involves the aspiration of fluid from the fetal thorax for therapeutic purposes.
